prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I kick my adult ”stepdaughter” out of my house?
New here so if I haven’t understood one of the rules please let me know!

I have a tricky situation I’m going through as of late.  I’m in a long term relationship.  We aren’t technically married, but we live as we are.  After a messy divorce she was never interested in being married again.  We’ve been dating for 8 years now.  I told her that the engagement is the best part so I proposed with both of us understanding that we would never actually get married.  She has an adult daughter who lives with us.  She’s 19. 

My “stepdaughter” and I have never had a good relationship despite my best efforts.  I really gave it everything I could to improve it over the years, but at best she was indifferent to me.  I gave up trying after buying her a car for her 16th birthday and she thanked her mother and didn’t acknowledge me at all even after her mother told her that I alone bought it for her.  

After that I’ve been just waiting her out for the most part.  I’m still kind when I’m around her, but if this is the relationship with me she wants then so be it.  I always assumed that when she turned 18 she would go off to school somewhere.  I was unfortunately wrong.  She instead started working at a salon in town.  She had taken cosmetology in BOCES in high school.  

I thought once she had been working for a bit and had saved enough she would then move out.  Wrong again.  I’ve asked her mother to see what her plans are for the future and if she plans on moving out on her own soon and my wife told me that she just wants to save as much as she can and keep living here.   My fiancé loves having her here, but I’ve been waiting so long to have the house be just my fiancé and I.   

I really feel like I’ve put my time in supporting her daughter and now especially with her having more than enough to move out on her own it’s time to push her out of the nest.  I’m not too concerned with her reaction.   To be blunt I don’t really care how she takes it.   My fiancé will probably be a little upset, but hopefully once the dust clears she will see that it’s for the best.  
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the author is in the wrong for wanting to kick out their adult stepdaughter. The scenario is that the stepdaughter is 19, living with them, and hasn't moved out despite being able to. The author's fiancé is technically his stepmother, but they're not married. The stepdaughter works and has money.

First, I need to consider legal aspects. The stepdaughter is an adult, so the author doesn't have legal authority over her. In most places, once someone is an adult, they can't be forced out unless there's a lease or legal agreement. If she's on the lease, he can't just kick her out without going through proper legal channels. But if she's on her mother's lease, maybe the mother would have to deal with it. However, the author isn't married to his fiancé, so maybe she's not on the lease? Not sure, but legal rights matter here.

Then there's the emotional aspect. The author tried to build a relationship but failed. The stepdaughter isn't responsive, which is frustrating. But using a public forum (like WIBTA) to decide to kick someone out can be seen as harsh, especially if it's sudden. The stepdaughter might have a right to privacy and stability. Also, the fiancé might be involved in the lease, so her input is important. The author is planning to proceed without considering her feelings too much, which could strain the relationship.

Social norms also play a role. It's common for young adults to live with family while establishing themselves, but it's also expected that they eventually move out. However, the author's approach might be abrupt and hurtful. The stepdaughter might not be ready, or maybe there are underlying issues she hasn't shared. The author is dismissing her feelings, which isn't ideal.

So, is the author in the wrong? Legally, maybe not if he can follow proper procedures. But ethically, being considerate is important. The author isn't giving her a chance to move out gracefully or address the situation with empathy. Publicly seeking validation might not be the best approach either. The answer likely leans towards A (yes, he's in the wrong) because of the lack of consideration for her feelings and the potential legal issues if he doesn't follow proper steps. But I need to confirm the legal part. If he can legally kick her out without being on the lease, maybe not. But generally, you can't just kick someone out without legal process. So maybe the answer is A because he's being inconsiderate and possibly not following proper procedures.
